Yet the evaluation concludes that the revised DSP assessment process is ‘appropriate relating to policy intent’ - ie they are doing exactly what they set out to do - that is to be heartless and cruel ( my words of course - not theirs).

They explicitly didn’t assess the broader economic and social costs and impact of not receiving DSP, despite the fact that making fewer people eligible has huge social costs, when the alternative is living in poverty on a Jobseeker allowance.

The evaluation looks at 'cost-effectiveness' of the changes - but only whether the costs of the extra assessment that has resulted in people being ineligible are more than the ‘average payments avoided’. Which they concluded they are: therefore the changes are cost effective!

These criticisms are what our Inquiry has heard, including that the application process is unreasonably burdensome, convoluted, difficult to navigate, that gaining medical evidence is difficult & expensive, and that there are  major barriers to access.

DSS have just released a report evaluating the DSP assessment process since it was revised in 2015. The changes have led to significantly fewer people being found eligible. The report contains LOTS of criticism of the process from advocacy organisations https://t.co/m3fC50wRJ5
Finally our Inquiry hearing into the DSP this afternoon heard from Services Australia & the Dept of Social Services. They told us that everything was fine of course.

Then there is the 10 yr waiting period for migrants to Australia to access the DSP. The UN committee overseeing our commitments under the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities says this waiting period is disability discrimination, and should be removed

Low literacy in English can mean that people who should qualify for DSP, then end up on Jobseeker ... then get cut off income support altogether when they don’t comply with the ‘mutual obligations’ and 'participation requirements' of Jobseeker.

Low English language & literacy skills, really complex processes,  huge costs of obtaining medical reports, difficulties in accessing interpreters & the government’s reliance on apps and mobile technologies can be insurmountable barriers; leaving people in abject poverty

We also heard this afternoon at our @AuSenate Inquiry into the DSP from advocates  working with people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds. They underlined how the DSP is failing CALD people. @NEDA_PeakBody  @petermc70

Medical costs when living on JobSeeker are huge. 
One person told us this morning that her gap fees can easily add up to over $100 week, which is impossible to afford when trying to survive on just $44 a day, the current rate of JobSeeker.

The barriers to receiving the DSP are huge and at times people's own medical practitioners don't understand their condition, let alone the government-appointed assessors. 
The process of getting the required medical evidence eludes people.

ME/CFS Australia’s submission included this quote "if I had access to financial and NDIS support earlier I probably could have hobbled along working part-time. Fighting the system broke me and bar some miracle I’ll never work again."
@GeoffHallmann

They feel they’re being bullied by the government, and are terrified that they will end up homeless.

There are 15,000 people with ME/CFS bed-bound in Australia, yet only 3000 get the DSP.
 
This is atrocious.

Most people living with cystic fibrosis, multiple sclerosis and ME/CFS are struggling. 

They’re usually rejected for the DSP, and are made to feel they’re trying to scam the system. And when rejected, they’re rarely told why in detail.
Another woman who has been on the DSP for 20 years told us of not being able to afford medication, spending 65% of her income on rent and waiting four years for an appointment to see a neurologist.

This woman’s disability means that she is only awake for six hours a day, so every waking minute is precious.
Yet, she has to use it up in frustrating pointless bureaucracy.

We heard the story of a woman on the DSP. She has a non-verbal autistic son who has been trying to claim the DSP for two years. 
They have to endlessly apply for jobs despite their employment services provider agreeing that it's just a pointless box-ticking exercise.
We heard powerful evidence this morning from people whose lives are impacted while applying for the DSP, and of people struggling to survive on JobSeeker when their DSP application gets rejected.

We are also seeing powerful evidence showing that first Nation peoples experience significant difficulties in accessing DSP, with less than 10% receiving DSP, compared with 24% actually living with a disability.

Lead by affected people and communities, I’m excited to get to work to tear down broken systems and fight to make sure everybody has access to the support and essentials we all need to lead meaningful and fulfilling lives. ✊💚

➡Forcing the Government to waive the unfair JobKeeper/JobSeeker debt
➡Ensuring the Aged Care sector gets $10 billion per year to implement the RC recommendations
➡Getting a RC into Robodebt to get to the bottom of how it happened and make sure it never happens again

Here’s a few things I’ll be working on (though this is not at all an exhaustive list)
➡Raising the rate of JobSeeker permanently to $80 a day
➡Scraping the cashless debit card
➡Making sure the DSL is available to everyone that needs it by fixing the broken eligibility criteria

We have a huge problem with income inequality and it’s getting worse. But it doesn’t need to be this way. Poverty is a political choice. It’s a policy choice. And we need to force whoever is in power to make different choices - because what we have now sure as hell ain’t working!

We’ve seen billionaires and corporations - who have seen their profits skyrocket during this pandemic - get huge government handouts through JobKeeper and other subsidies. All the while millions of Australians are struggling to keep their heads above water.

Yet right now, over half a million people in lockdown in Victoria, NSW and the ACT alone are living on payments below the poverty line because the Morrison Government ripped away income support when people needed it most.

No one in a wealthy country like ours should have to make a choice between keeping a roof over their head, or paying for their prescription, or eating, or having clothes and shoes that aren’t falling apart. These essentials should be non-negotiable.
For the first time in many, many years, people didn’t have to worry that their whole world could come crashing down at any moment simply because they didn’t have enough to get by.

Last year, when people started receiving the Coronavirus Supplement and the moratorium on evictions, we finally saw what it could be like if we designed our economy to work for everyone, not just the mega-wealthy few.

Rachel was an absolute force of nature in the Senate for over 16 years fighting for equality. So I have some very big shoes to fill, but I promise to do all I can to be your advocate inside Parliament, working  to make sure no one in this wealthy country is living in poverty.

This summer’s bushfires fundamentally changed Victoria’s forests, killing hundreds of millions of animals. The state and federal governments are ignoring these alarm bells. Victoria cannot continue on this path of logging destruction.

It is clear from the agreement that it would be very easy for future Labor or Liberal governments to extend logging beyond 2030, despite the Andrews government’s commitment last year to end native forest logging.

Even after events like last summer's devastating bushfires in East Gippsland there is no requirement to do a ‘major event review’, let alone commit to scaling back logging to protect areas of unburnt forest.

None of the changes, like Major Event Reviews, tighter timelines to assess how bad things are for threatened species, acknowledgement of climate change or consulting with Traditional Owners, have any teeth.

The updated Regional Forest Agreements #RFAs contain a lot of fine-sounding words, but the harsh reality is that they lock in logging for another 10 years, fast-track extinction, and destroy animal habitat, carbon stores and fresh water sources.

Last night the Vic Govt released key details of the 10-year extension to forest logging laws in Victoria, signed off this week. These agreements are co-signed by Vic/Fed govts. Here's my read on it so far...

20 March 2017 meeting: Department of Environment & Energy says it didn't take any notes during that meeting.  Why not?? Taking notes is a critical function of public service, with clear guidelines in Code of Conduct. #grassgate #auspol

Department of Environment and Energy knew compliance action was underway, knew familiar link between Jam Lands and Minister Taylor, but did not proactively say that the Dept would not discuss compliance in the meeting. #grasslands #auspol

Department of Environment and Energy says strong sentiment from senators and members of parliament that the broader EPBC Act review in 2019 would be too long a wait and wanted an ag review earlier. Sense of urgency was absolutely there. #auspol
At the March 2017 meeting, Minister Taylor did not declare his financial interest in Jamland to the Department of Environment and Energy #auspol #grasslands

Timeline offered by dept: Alleged unlawful clearing by Jam Land occurred in Oct 2016, reported Nov 2016, 7 March 2017 Department met with Jam Land, 8 March Minister Frydenberg wrote to dept to ask them to meet with Taylor. #auspol #grassgate

When did the Department become aware that Minister Taylor had financial interest in #JamLand & compliance action? Dept says aware at the time that the request came in for the meeting in March 2017. Can't answer how the Department was made aware. Dept. to take q on notice #auspol
Department can't give answer as to why there was a focus on the agriculture sector for the Craik review (when ag represents only 2.7% of all referrals under the EPBC Act). #auspol
Up now at the Canberra senate hearing about grasslands and the faunal extinction crisis: officers of the Department of the Environment & Energy. #auspol #greens

More from the senate hearing into grasslands and faunal extinction crisis: Dr Wendy Craik says she was aware that there was an investigation underway when visiting the Monaro grasslands while completing the ag review.

Q to Dr Craik: The farmers of Jam Lands who have been alleged of poisoning, do you think credible that they didn't know what they were doing? Says she is sure they knew what they were doing, but can't confirm knowledge of EPBC Act interaction. #grassgate #auspol

Only 2.7% of referrals to the EPBC Act come from agriculture (about 10 per year). Interesting that ag was then given its own special report when there was a broader EPBC report due in 2019 anyway🤔 #grassgate #auspol
Ag review timing: Think we started doing the review in April last year - may have been asked in February, says Craik.

Up now in Canberra senate hearing into grasslands and threatened species: Dr Wendy Craik, author of the review of interactions between the EPBC Act and the agriculture
sector #auspol

How much discussion of compliance action undertaken by Taylor/Jam Land was there in Nationals Party Room meeting? - Wacka says he asked departmental advisor and Frydenberg to 'back off a bit'. #auspol #grassgate
Apologies for previous incorrect spelling of Former Senator John 'Wacka' Williams!

WakKa says: May have had conversation with Frydenberg about the issue prior to the Nationals Party Room meeting with Frydenberg. After the discussion with Frydenberg, Craik ag review was put into place. Interesting timeline #auspol #grasslands

Timeline of Waka on #grasslands saga, he says: - 1. Heard Taylor on ABC Country Hour early 2018. 2. Rang Richard Taylor on phone same day as broadcast. 3. Few weeks later, took to Nationals Party Room. This would have been prior to Dr Craik's review of ag and EPBC Act #auspol

Now up at grasslands senate hearing - Former Senator John 'Waka' Williams: says he first heard grasslands story on ABC Country Hour in early 2018. Called then-Enviro Minister Josh Frydenberg to National Party room to talk about the issue Taylor was facing. #auspol

More from the #Grasslands threatened species panel at senate hearing: What happens to the offsets when development pressure starts at those locations? Flawed concept and a net loss in most occasions. No long term protection guaranteed. 🙁

From the #Grasslands threatened species panel at senate hearing: No science behind offsetting and no adequate monitoring of the outcomes of offsetting. Yet, offsets are used as a major tool for getting rid of a problem, says Dr Hocking, Adjunct Senior Lecturer, La Trobe #auspol

From the Grasslands threatened species panel at senate hearing - Ms Sharp from Friends of Grasslands says there is deliberate clearing by farmers of lands with threatened species, Jamland clearing Monaro grasslands is one example. #auspol

EPBC Act in principle is a good act, but in practice is not performing its function. Needs to be taken out of the political context and have an independent approach, says Dr Hocking of La Trobe University

EPBC Act has not been effective in protecting threatened species in rural areas. Intensive farming should not exceed 1/3 of the landscape (though it often has) - beyond that threshold, we begin to lose species, says Dr McIntyre of ANU.
Senate public hearing about grasslands and Australia's faunal extinction crisis is about to kick off in Canberra now. Will be tweeting throughout the day to keep you updated. #auspol #greens

And it mustn’t stop at private EVs. We need electric buses, we need investment in public transport, we need increased spending on cycling. The climate challenge demands it #SmS2019
We need policies. We need government working with business, academia and civil society to deliver the change #SmS2019
But it doesn’t have to be this way. With strong government leadership and industry policy, we could be world leaders. But we must embrace the transition #SmS2019
In this scenario, we play no part in the global battery or auto manufacturing business. We do not prepare the charging network to service regional and low income earners. We are left behind.

There are two ways the EV transition can happen here in Australia. The first: we sit by and watch as other countries take the lead. We stay the dumping ground for high polluting models and Australia remains a technology taker #SmS2019
Sadly over 1500 Australian’s die each year from vehicle pollution. We could save thousands of lives and billions of dollars in health costs #SmS2019
That report found that we could increase GDP by $2.9b and 13400 new jobs all while dramatically cutting emissions #SmS2019

However if you look around Australia, you wouldn’t know any of this is happening. Less than 0.5% of new sales are EVs... in Norway it’s 50% #SmS2019
Every day brings new evidence that the 21st century global economy is rapidly shifting to clean energy #SmS2019
Major automakers are coming to the inevitable conclusion that the countries in which they make the majority of their sales are demanding that the transport sector radically reduce emissions #SmS2019
The Paris Agreement says that we MUST act, voters around the world demanding the shift to a zero carbon economy #SmS2019
We have to look honestly and unflinchingly at what’s ahead if we don’t cut our carbon pollution #SmS2019
